3.body:
Use your brain. You think any country will use nukes first when using them means your country will be destroyed too? You bring a gun to a knife fight because then you are stronger. If you have the advantage then you would use nukes. But there is no advantage with nukes because the other side has them too. 3.author: Proper-Abies208
3.body:
You believe its one man's choice? There have been two incidents in history where Russia thought it was under attack by America and wanted to fire nukes towards America. On both cases one man stopped the nukes from being fired. 

In 1962 and 1983 there were incidents but it didn't lead to a nuclear war because Russians stopped the other Russians from firing. And that will also happen should Putin decide that he will take all of Russia down with him. Many russians may side with Putin, but when it really boils down to it , do you think people will do what Putin wants? They will push the buttons knowing that means the end of their own wife, husband, children, parents, friends, perhaps the whole world?  And let's assume Russia does decide it will nuke the West. Then where will it start? With the US? Then France and UK retaliate. Nuke them all three? Then any of the 750 US bases could retaliate. Nuke them too? Then a nuclear submarine could retaliate. Nuke them too? Then us bases in Europe that have US missiles pointing at Russia could retaliate. 
It can't be done. Russia will also stop the exists of it fires nuclear missiles.

5.author: TheSoundOfRealism
5.body: Look dude, you’re a little all over the place. First you try the racism approach, it doesn’t work, next you’re framing him contributing his knowledge as a special risk? He’s already crossed the line in their eyes by doing what he did. If they are determined, they will do whatever they please ultimately, with or without an intel debrief from him. This is a standard procedure with prisoners of war and not unreasonable as recognized by most of the world. Also you are forgetting, prior to his announcement, he was still military, therefore a participant. The pragmatism element of things has already been explained to you, but blew over your head in the last comments evidently. The economy of Ukraine is the ultimate consideration after unparalleled destruction has been committed to it by an invading nation. It’s not just him, it’s the military in general.

5.author: Almaegen
5.body:
No, you deflected the "labor program" for Russians comment by saying you meant just military members but this man is not a military member so I'm not seeing your point. 

> you’re framing him contributing his knowledge as a special risk

Nice strawman but the only involvement in "helping the war effort" for an ex Russian soldier would be fighting or removing mines. Ukraine would never let him into anything else so yes its a risk. Also what knowledge transfer is this soldier going to give? Nothing he saw will have any importance outside of being a witness to war crimes. 

>This is a standard procedure with prisoners of war and not unreasonable as recognized by most of the world

Which does not matter because he is neither in a war or a prisoner.

>Also you are forgetting, prior to his announcement, he was still military, therefore a participant. 

A participant in a nations military, who did not commit war crimes and who objected and defected as soon as he could before the war was resolved.  Also with that mindset should we start pulling soldiers from NATO militaries to do forced labor in Iraq?  


>The pragmatism element of things has already been explained to you

Or just maybe you are trying to make unrealistic ideological demands seem pragmatic when they are in reality immoral and unjust.

> It’s not just him, it’s the military in general

Which will be shouldered by the Russian state and not by the legal combatants which the state used. Legally POWs can be used but this man is no POW he is a civilian political refugee.

5.author: TheSoundOfRealism
5.body: You’re determined to argue about nothing. I never deflected, he is military even if he denounced it. It still accounts for his past status before denouncement. Words don’t take away status like that. Secondly, you saying the only way we can use him is as a mine clearer is about the most unintelligible mumbling you’ve uttered so far. He can do volunteer labor, rescue efforts, medical, or many other services that we could keep listing. Third, the POW reference was to point out that it is a widely accepted standard worldwide and an overall normal and humane practice, another one that flew by you. Lastly, the state will never pay, they’ve used those exact men for a litany of war crimes and overall economic damage. My point still stands. Argue with a wall and pick apart its talking points.

6.body:

6.author: crimsonjava
6.body:
...everything you wrote is bizarrely wrong and not how the world works at all.

The US military making a choice to directly attack Russian forces and subsequently involving NATO (by the triggering of Article V if Russia shoots back) would be *by definition* a war, even if neither nuclear power uses their nukes.   This is why the US military doesn't operate within Ukraine and delivers weapons to Poland do be driven across the border by Ukrainian military members.  This is why Russia doesn't bomb vehicle depots across the border in Poland.  This is why everyone panicked when the missile accidentally hit those Polish farmers and for a moment everything thought it might be a Russian one (which could've triggered Article V and brought NATO into the war.)

6.author: letsgocrazy
6.body:
You didn't say "a war" though did you, you said "world war 3".

If you need help with any more stuff like this, just let me know.

6.author: crimsonjava
6.body: I get that you're struggling to understand this, so I will spell it out slowly: if the US enters a war with Russia, it could trigger the mutual defense pact of NATO which would bring in all of our Western European allies.  So two nuclear powers + NATO (which has two additional nuclear powers) all fighting is effectively world war III.  The mistake you're likely making is assuming world war III = nuclear war, which it obviously doesn't, although the danger would be that it could escalate which is why we spend so might energy trying to avoid direct conflict.

16.author: StressedPizzaEater
16.body:
The C model is uparmored and can only transport 6 soldiers.
It has improved AC and laser range finder and filters.

It's the latest domestic Swedish version of CV90 and has served in Afghanistan.

The export version MkI - IV have incremental improvements.
The MkIV does have atgm pod which can shoot Spike LR or Akeron atgm missiles but the Swedish version does not yet have this capabilities but they are slated for modernization.

But since it has hatches on the soldier compartment the soldiers can easily pop up with an NLAW or Javelin 

Export versions have the Bushmaster chain gun between 30-35mm where as the Swedish army uses Bofors 40mm

22.author: Strict-Toe3538
22.body:
The middle East exists because of the fall of the ottoman empire, and many of the states that exist today barely operate as nations. Iraq is split 3 ways (sunnies, Shia, kurdish) Syria (rebel, gov, kurdish).. Lebanon is basically two countries with two separate armies, gov and hezbollah.
You say the middle East hasn't been balkanised then go on to describe the exact scenario of how it was balkanised.

22.author: freshlypuckeredbutt
22.body:
It’s sort of splitting hairs because the Balkans and the middle east were both under ottoman rule, but balkanization isn’t just splitting up a country, it also refers to making governmental entities around ethnicity. 

Yugoslavia was split up internally based on ethnic groups, which was possible because they were geopolitically isolated. The borders of middle eastern countries were decided by european powers working with Islam-centric kings regardless of the many ethnicities and tribes that existed in arabia.

Before the fall of the Ottoman empire both the balkans and arabia were loosely defined principalities with tribal infighting. They just split up in different ways and for different reasons. European nation-building vs culturally defined nations.

31.author: Chimpville
31.body:
I read some similar (but probably less authoritative) things mainly on Quora and similar when I was trying to understand where you were coming from.

Even from the article you posted by a serving military judge, albeit a person who very much has every incentive to be extremely guarded and noncommittal, they at best describe the distinction as 'blurred' and advise only to be 'attentive' and 'vigilant'. This seems more like a warning to legal practitioners to expect a defence to be cobbled together, not that it has any true merit.

It'd seem something of a legal failure not to classify a person who was drawn out of prison, offered wads of cash plus their freedom, and then operated under the command of Prigozhin, a civilian political advisor to *not* be a mercenary. Were we talking about pre-2022 Wagner where so many of their forces were regular, serving soldiers on a plausible-deniability-gap-year from their regular service, I'd agree.. but even then, Russia as a government have after all on several occasions denied having OPCON of Wagner.  


Edit: I want to make it clear that believe anybody, even a mercenary, should be treated with dignity and care in capture, so am not arguing that UAF or anybody else should exclude them in practice.. I'm just defending the integrity of my joke.

31.author: Chimpville
31.body:
There has been a very clear divide between Wagner under Prigozhin and the armed forces under Shoigu and Gerasimov - statements from each claiming individual, non-joint successes, especially over Solidar. Wagner even awarded their own Wagner medal for it. The medals the Russians have been giving to Wagner soldiers is the [medal for courage](https://www.identifymedals.com/database/medals-by-country/russia-ussr-medals/the-medal-for-courage/) which is not exclusively an armed-forces medal, it is available to citizens and even non-citizens in other capacities.

But all in all, Wagner and the Russian military leadership have gone through pains describe themselves as being separate, even to the point the Kremlin has denied claims that Prigozhin made about capturing Solidar, which they later claimed for themselves. There's also things like this:

[In a video message, Prigozhin described Wagner as a fully independent force with its own aircraft, tanks, rockets and artillery.](https://www.reuters.com/world/europe/russias-prigozhin-boasts-wagner-prowess-amid-wrangling-with-defence-2023-01-14/)

​

Edit: spelling

31.author: Chimpville
31.body:
Thank you.. I'm going to consider my joke intact!

I was very tired when I wrote the last reply so sorry it was unclear.

I think I saw you make a point about Wagner being all Russian? I believe in Ukraine we've seen Serbian, German and even [a Zambian](https://www.africanews.com/2022/11/29/unknown-aircraft-targets-wagner-base-in-c-african-republic//) filmed, killed or captured fighting for Wagner so far.

The Serbian president criticised and asked Wagner to stop recruiting in Serbia for the war in Ukraine. [Which they denied of course.](https://www.reuters.com/world/europe/russias-wagner-group-denies-recruiting-serbs-fight-ukraine-2023-01-20/)  


I think all that can be said for Wagner soldier's claims to not be mercenaries is that it is a very thin and likely weak legal semantical defence which hopefully wouldn't hold in the face of all the evidence(from this or multiple other conflicts they were involved in), is certainly not in the spirit or intention of the conventions and has absolutely no basis on practical terms. If they are mercenary-ish... the ish is basically silent.  


Thank you very much for the discussion!

40.author: MrJqmbo
40.body:
Sure, although that isn’t surprising, The recent Azov Regiment statement was directed to Ukrainian media who were conflating the two units. People getting confused isn’t indicative of their actual relationship, the Azov SSO telegram identified them as veterans of the Azov movement who formed a volunteer formation after February 24th. 

It’s certainly possible that there was a de facto connection and partnership, but the official statements indicate a differentiation

40.author: its_a_metaphor_morty
40.body:
Interesting. It's very hard to find good info on SSO in particular, and they used the same insignia. I know Kraken is a separate unit with ex-Azov members who started it, but as far as I knew SSO was just the northern part of the batallion.

edit: I found a Stanford (organisation not uni) piece which states that the Kyiv branch is Azov proper but formed by the movement and separate from the Southern batallion, which makes sense.

"In line with this announcement, the Azov Movement established several new military units separate from the National Guard Regiment. First, and most prominently, Azov formed a TDF unit in Kyiv. The Azov Kyiv TDF involved many prominent veterans of the original Azov Battalion and National Guard Regiment who became involved in the National Corps and other Azov Movement structures such as ex-Azov Regiment commander and National Corps chief of staff Maksym Zhorin.[79] National Corps’ late deputy secretary for ideology Mykola Kravchenko was also an officer in the unit when he died during the defense of Kyiv.[80] A force of expatriate Belarusian combatants, including Azov veterans, also fought as part of the Azov Kyiv TDF before forming the separate Kastus Kalinouski Battalion.[81]"

https://cisac.fsi.stanford.edu/mappingmilitants/profiles/azov-battalion

40.author: MrJqmbo
40.body: I think a lot of the issue is that they were founded by Azov veterans, including the likes of Andriy Biletsky. Who was instrumental in the Azov movement and the first commander of the OG battalion. The two units definitely shared an affinity for one another, but I think that’s where it stops. I don’t believe there are any indications that SSO obeyed orders from the Regiments overall commander, and I don’t recall any instances of the Azov Regiment official telegram sharing SSO materials

40.author: its_a_metaphor_morty
40.body: It's pretty convoluted, the article I cited indicates that Kyiv SSO was formed by Azov movement proper, and also that ex Southern batallion members were key in manning it. The use of the same insignia, flags and organisation has made the water extremely muddy. On top of that Ukrainian unit relationships are complex enough that I don't even trust a statement from one person from one group to even mean much.

The goal of the Infantryman isn't to kill the enemy. If you have gotten training as an infantryman, you'd know this. Doubleshot to centermass, roughly navel height. That will disable a fighter, which is the goal. I repeat again, when you **injure** a combatant enough to take away their ability to fight, you are more successfully binding enemy resources, resources they use to wage war. If you happen to kill some one directly, you're doing a worse job than you are when you injure them.

And a gutshot usually does mean death.

Still, your goals isn't to kill. It's to win. And one wins wars by destroying the enemy's ability to fight and will to fight. Which again, injuring does **better** than killing.

If one could make the perfect marksman, then a hit to the armpit/shoulder of the side they shoot on would be ideal, as it prevents them from continuing to fight, leaves them alive but screaming for help, and their partner/squad mates will have to discontinue their fighting to staunch the bleeding. 46.author: Sweet_Coat7963
46.body:
Rockets are unguided munitions. When you’re throwing the nose that high you’re sending those munitions ~6km away and you don’t stand a chance of hitting anything specific. You’re just lobbing them down range. The only time I’ve ever done that was in initial flight school training, and it’s more useful/effective tactic when you have a troop of helicopters in line doing it. In fact I specifically remember being told “you’ll never do this in combat, but we’re still going to demo the maneuver”.

Effective fire with these 2.75” rockets is to bump up, then fly down toward the target while shooting. We call that a CCA (close combat attack). It’s a lot of fun.

52.author: Quietabandon
52.body:
It’s not just training. It is having sufficient fuel tankers. It’s having maintenance support. Its having the real time communication. It’s coordinating these two things. It’s protecting your soft skinned untracked support vehicles. 

And it’s not something you can just quickly train. You can train individuals in certain tasks but the US army has a deeply experienced NCO core with institutional memory, training and experience in all of these systems as well as commissioned officers with years of experience and training. Plus in the US money is no object. In non peer conflicts like Afghanistan and Iraq US delivered fuel to advance units at a cost of $100s per gallon. 

Leopards are a better fit because they are easier to service, less fuel hungry,  will be the predominant type of vehicle. Supporting one vehicle type is a huge advantage. Simplifies training. Simplifies logistics. And if the type is more fuel efficient simplifies fuel supply. 

Also the Leopards run on diesel. The Abrams can take many fuels but prefers JP8 jet fuel. Running on other fuels can limit range and performance, and increase maintenance cycles. 

You dismiss these things as trivial but they are a huge part of warfare and a huge cost in blood and treasure. There are few countries that can do it. Russias failure at this is one reason they are failing. 

I have no doubt Ukrainians are very capable but even they seem to prefer Leopards - which run on diesel, are plentiful, are very capable, and are easier to support.

Fielding 200 or so leopards will make a huge difference and be easier to support than 30
Abrams and 155 Leopards and 14 Challengers. 

No logistics person will tell you that fielding mixed fleets is a good idea. There are 100s of Leopards in Europe that can be readily transferred to Ukraine quickly and you can train all your crews on variants of vehicle instead of different vehicles with different power plants. 

Plus you have a ton of trained technicians for Leopards all of Europe. It would make more sense to accelerate delivery of Abrams to Poland so that their leopards could go to Ukraine.

I'm aware that Soviet and modern Russia have done everything in their power to villainize any gestures of Ukrainian pride and independence as "Nazism". I don't fall for any of that shit which is why I still vehemently support Ukraine financially and through helping Ukrainian refugees (I was in Warsaw when the war began, a lot of people needed homes).

53.author: AngryUkrainian1337
53.body:
>My guy, I'm not referencing Russian propaganda. I'm referencing facts. This isn't up for discussion.

I don't mean that as "you're spreading Russian propaganda / you're a Russian agent". I'm just stating that those facts are brought to you by Russian propaganda (directly or not directly).   


>'Azov’s founder, Andriy Biletsky, stated it was Ukraine’s mission to “Lead the white races of the world in a final crusade… against semite-led subhumans.”'  


I'm not able to find this quote in Ukrainian or English. I can see links to dead articles, russian bots on twitter, and Russian websites.  
It's definitely not a part of the ideology, but I'm really curious to find the origin of this quote.

1) I am well aware of Andriy Biletsky. He is from my city. He is not the smartest guy. He was arrested and spent time in jail for "extremism" in 2010-2011. "Patriots of Ukraine" are from Kharkiv, and they worked the government (pro-Russian) for some time. They used Russian money to grow.  
2) He was replaced as a commander of Azov after a few months.  
3) He doesn't have power in Ukraine.  


Probably, another fact that you considered to mention is his nickname "White Chieftain" (Vozhd). It is usually presented as a part of "white supremacy". But "white" translated as "bilyy" in Ukraine. It's a part of his last name. So, "White" is a legit nickname for him. It sounds better in Ukrainian than in English.  


Vozhd/Chieftain - just a hierarchy thing.   


>The chosen iconography isn't some set of tragically misunderstood symbols. They use the Wolfsangel, the symbol of multiple SS divisions, a rotated version of the original "Z" Nazi party symbol

No, they use "Idea of the Nation". Created by merging N+I letters together. It has an entire story behind it. This a fully legit symbol, it was used in Ukraine for more than 30 years.  


The average person doesn't know all Nazis symbols by heart. You need to show them.  
"Look this a Wolfsangel symbol, this is a "Idea of the Nation" symbol. See the difference?". Russian propaganda does this very well.  


As far as you correctly mentioned, the original "Z". It's a Z with a '-'. Russian currently uses 'Z' everywhere. T-shirts, TVs, cars, books, logos, literally everywhere. They style their names as "Vладимир КараZин" (Vladimir KaraZin).  
This a textbook "hate symbol". The new swastika.   


AZOV uses its symbol as a logo, but we discussing the AZOV symbol, not the Russian one :)  
Shifting the focus of the audience is also a textbook trick of the Russian Propaganda machine.  


>These symbols have next to no historical significance to Ukraine.

I strongly do not agree here. During the WW2, Ukrainian soldiers fought in  
1) Red Army / Soviet Union  
2) SS Forces (1st Galician, Roland, Nachtigall)  
3) Ukrainian Nationalists (OUN)  


In the Soviet Union, the 2nd and 3rd parts were erased from our history. We learned only about the Soviet Heroes. After the fall of the Soviet Union, Ukraine started slowly to accept them as part of its history.   
The process is described only as "glorifying of Ukrainian Neo-Nazis" by Russia. This is not true, we learn good & ugly about them.  


It is extremely important to know and understand history in order to not repeat it. Russia missed this lesson.  


>From this video, it looks like Azov has done a lot of work to clean up their image. I'm hoping that continues.

Again, from my point of view, Azov did absolutely nothing to 'clean up'. They really don't care about comments on Reddit or Youtube.  
But we had "Hey, Americans think that the N+I symbol is a Nazi symbol, let's replace it. Fuck, we've already changed our logo 4 times.". They adopted the trident symbol. No one openly uses or used Nazi symbols.

  
1) Ukrainian Nationalism existed for centuries. Ukrainians had dozens of revolts against Russia, Poland and other countries.   
2) the Soviet Union contained 15 republics with different cultures and nations.  
\- slavic orthodox white (Belorus, Ukraine, Russia)  
\- muslim (Dagestan, Ichkeria, Chehnya, Crimean Tatars)  
\- central asians (Kazakstan, Tadjikistan, Uzbekistan, Tukmenistan, Kyrgystan)  
\- caucasus  


We had A LOT of internal issues, we had them after the Soviet Union, and ex-Soviet countries still have them.  


Americans often bring their own experience and label things as "racism" or "white supremacy" but these problems have absolutely different roots.

57.author: _Raven_Roth
57.body:
Halyna from Avdiivka in Donetsk Oblast has been working here since March 2022. The local city council regularly posts vacancies online, which is where she found the ad for this position.

“We want the war to end and to return home. But, unfortunately, there is no place now, because everything [in Donbas] is occupied or bombed. We realize that this will last for some time,” she adds.
Halyna describes Novovolynsk as “very similar” to her hometown. Like much of the Donbas, Novovolynsk is a mining city.

“Everything is the same here, except for the fact that the Ukrainian language is spoken everywhere. But for me, Ukrainian is my mother tongue,” 

Halyna adds.
Another employee, Nina, is a Mykolayiv native. She studied to become a seamstress 30 years ago but instead spent years working in a juice factory. “Now this sewing knowledge came in handy,” Nina smiles.

Over time, the team’s composition has changed because some members returned to their liberated cities in Kyiv and Chernihiv oblasts after hostilities ended there. Every day, four company workers sew eight military unloading systems.

“Nowadays, only the lazy do not produce [such products] in Ukraine. And I have to admit that our [military] cares about their appearance, in terms of the color and design. As one customer put it: it will be elegant for me. Even there [on the frontlines], they strive for elegance,” Olena says.

57.author: _Raven_Roth
57.body:
Three new cafés opened by displaced persons enrich Novovolynsk’s social life
The Novovolynsk city council received 30 applications from businesses willing to relocate. According to the city mayor, about 20 businesses have already transferred to Novovolynsk. Additionally, persons who moved to Novovolynsk due to the war opened at least three new cafés in the city.

The blue design of Sleep Sugar coffee shop near Novovolynsk park reminds a coastal city. This is not a coincidence, as its owner was making coffee on the Black Sea coast in Odesa, where he worked in a restaurant business.

Vadym, 31, is originally from Novovolynsk but he has been studying and working in Odesa for the past twelve years. After returning to Novovolynsk following Russia’s full-scale invasion, he decided it was time to “make coffee ourselves.” Together with his Novovolynsk-native friend Vlad, they opened Sleep Sugar Coffee Point.

“We wanted to make an atmospheric place, not one where one buys coffee and immediately forgets about it,” Vadym explains. “Here in Novovolynsk, people have fallen in love with our coffee, and many displaced people from Kherson and Mykolayiv also visit us. When we talk to them, they all want to go home. Even though Novovolynsk is a pleasant place to live, people still long to return home.”
Another café was relocated from Irpin, a town near Kyiv that was devastated by Russia’s 2022 invasion and occupation. A couple, Vitaliy and Valeriya, had run a family business in Irpin for a decade. The war forced the family with a 10-month-old baby to leave their home.

After the first month in Novovolynsk, Vitaliy and Valeriya realized that the town was a good fit for opening a café. They kept the name of their café in Irpin, and the Taddy Coffee signboard was sent directly from there to Novovolynsk. Having found a place near a grass plot, they arranged a summer site with a playground at the entrance. Taddy Coffee contributes 10% of its profits to the Armed Forces of Ukraine.

57.author: _Raven_Roth
57.body:
Another couple, Yuliya and Ihor were working in the music industry in Kyiv; Yuliya arranged concerts for famous Ukrainian musicians, and Ihor made musical arrangements for them. When the family visited Yuliya’s hometown of Novovolynsk for Easter they were impressed with how the town had developed in recent years and decided to extend their stay.

Every morning in Kyiv, they had a tradition of enjoying coffee with croissants at one of their favorite cafés. However, in the spring, they could not find one in Novovolynsk. So they decided to create such a place themselves.

“Over the past two years, the city [Novovolynsk] has changed greatly; it has become more beautiful and well-kept, and the locals are friendly. But my husband and I were missing delicious coffee. We are used to 100% Arabica, which couldn’t find here. So we decided to simultaneously help the economy and start our own business, where the locals can enjoy delicious coffee. I even studied to become a barista for this,” says Yuliya.

Despite the war, it took them only one month to find a location and open Mika café. They even agreed on the delivery of their favorite croissants all the way from Kyiv to Novovolynsk.

Mika is now not only a favorite coffee spot among locals but also a venue for concerts featuring famous Ukrainian artists, with whom the couple work. Just outside the café, charity concerts are frequently held to raise funds for the needs of Ukraine’s Armed Forces.

57.author: _Raven_Roth
57.body:
For us, this is not a business, but something we love; we truly enjoy what we do,” Yuliya explains.
Local cafés support both the military, too. 

For example, a customer in Felicita Novovolynsk can choose a meal from a separate menu, from where 100% of the proceeds are donated to Ukraine’s Armed Forces. In particular, the restaurant raised funds for a vehicle for the military. Besides, the café’s waiters decided to donate 50% of all tips to the army.

>BERLIN, Sept 12 (Reuters) - Germany must meet NATO's 2% of GDP military spending target over the long term even after a 100 billion euro ($101 billion) special fund is used up and accept a military leadership role it earlier shied away from, its defence minister said on Monday.

So, unfortunately, as I said, it is required that countries browbeat Germany into acting in a responsible fashion, because otherwise, they simply will not.  Someday, perhaps, Germany will tire of being the recalcitrant child of Europe, and get its act together, and such will no longer be required.

One can hope, anyway.

>Germany promised swift tank swaps to aid Ukraine. It hasn’t happened.

>BERLIN — It’s a hot candidate for the German word of the year — and increasingly a synonym for the problems surrounding Berlin’s military support for Ukraine: “Ringtausch.”Unlike its literal meaning — the exchange of rings at a wedding — the word has come to encompass the tank-swap scheme German Chancellor Olaf Scholz proposed in April. His promise: If Germany’s European allies sent Ukraine their older tanks, Berlin would quickly replace those vehicles from its own supply.Three months later, however, Berlin is struggling to implement many of these deals, leading to a delay in tank deliveries to Ukraine as the country tries to fend off Russian advances in the east and prepares an offensive aiming to reconquer territory in the south.  
>  
>“The Ringtausch has become a dead end because of Chancellor Scholz’s hesitancy,” said Friedrich Merz, leader of Germany’s main opposition party, the Christian Democratic Union (CDU). “It should give him some food for thought that even Poland — one of our most important partners — is now sharply criticizing the German government for its inaction.”

>“That’s just not adequate,” Kiesewetter added. “A senior official in the Polish foreign ministry told me: ‘If it had been at least a battalion, meaning 48 to 56 Leopard tanks, that could have been acceptable.’ But we were not willing to provide that — and all this is leading to massive damage to Germany’s reputation in eastern Europe.”

The agreement, expected to be officially announced in Poland on Wednesday, will see Warsaw purchase 980 tanks based on the South Korean K2 model, 648 self-propelled K9 armored howitzers, and 48 FA-50 fighter jets, the ministry said. It would not confirm the value of the deal.

Every state has its reasons for why they act the way they do. Russia is a rapidly declining relic of the pre-Soviet era. It’s population growth has become stagnant if not declining, it’s economy is outdated, the government is corrupt, the list goes on. They’ve lost their superpower status after the collapse of the USSR and have been making their way attempting to recapture their former status. Or at the very least reduce American influence and power globally, bringing the world to a multipolar state. Ukraine is most likely their (specifically Putin’s) last ditch attempt at returning to the the multipolar order. 

You assume they have no ammo, you assume they’re bumpkins because you’ve been inundated with propaganda and you’ve attached emotional support to reason and logic. That’s your problem. We’re talking about western tanks, it’s a thread about western tanks and their influence in the war. Again, allowing your emotions and paranoia to get the better of you. Why, when, and where else would I be discussing these things? Don’t look too far into things, take them at face value. 

Again, I have no sympathies, objectivity is my goal. However I feel is irrelevant to reality. Being all gung-ho for Ukraine isn’t going to magically make them win, the same can be said for Russia. Hating on Russia won’t make them lose, the same for Ukraine. Things will play out the way they’ll play out. I’m merely observing. As they have been doing, regardless of what you or I say.

65.author: Pvt_Numnutz1
65.body: That's blowing it a bit out of proportion, as Ukraine is not a member of NATO as of yet.

65.author: JazzHands1986
65.body: No but their ability to supply Ukraine could have been much better had military spending been adequate over the years.

65.author: Pvt_Numnutz1
65.body:
Let's be real, it's Spain, not exactly a European military juggernaut. Even had they doubled their military spending the countries like the US, England, Germany etc would still have a gargantuan divide. 

It's usually Americans who make this point about spending, and I always want to say that this is the American world order, the western world order. It's kinda silly to be upset about having to pay the biggest share to defacto run/police the world.

65.author: JazzHands1986
65.body: It's not just Spain though is it. I am not upset at what role the US provides or what it pays just that other countries aren't pulling their weight. It showed that if you don't spend the right amounts during peace time you'll run into problems during times of war. If China attacked Taiwain right now the west would be in real trouble trying to fight both fronts and supplying both countries with weapons.

65.author: Pvt_Numnutz1
65.body:
Well, again that line of thinking seems to me to be directly related to the amount that the US spends. 

"Other countries not pulling their weight" specifically. Yes the US learned some lessons from WWII and the cold war, and has developed our military spending to account for both china and Russia as our peer rivals (militarily ofc) but America is the world superpower, not every country in  NATO has those same global strategic ambitions, like Spain, Luxemburg, Norway or Turkey. I would argue that for some nations the draw of being in the alliance is specifically being under the blanket of the massive American military umbrella, and in turn some of those countries might be more strategic in geography than in their actual fighting force, like the Bosporus straight. 

I agree that European countries do need to reevaluate their own defense capabilities and needs, and this war in Ukraine has made that need plain as day, I think the courage that Ukrainians are showing in the face of Russian aggression has been inspiring to many, certainly the Baltic states and Poland, plus galvanizing Sweden and Finland to apply to join which is huge for many reasons. They have already started raising those budgets.

If China attacked Taiwan the world would be in a very serious situation, much more so than just the logistical problems with supplying them with weapons, besides you'd have to get them there before any invasion anyway so kind of a moot point.

65.author: JazzHands1986
65.body: Not to mention, the US would most likely be directly involved as it can't really afford to lose Taiwan.  That's all I was saying is that Nato needs to maintain a certain threshold for spending compared to gdp for all countries. Just so they are prepared in proportion to their allies to help, should a conflict break out.

65.author: Pvt_Numnutz1
65.body: Just for clarities sake, were you meaning before they recently raised their defense budgets? Or do you think they still have not raised them enough?

65.author: JazzHands1986
65.body: No I think that things will be a lot different after this conflict. I don't think that these countries feel they can afford to be complacent with defense spending after what they learned from the Ukraine situation.

66.author: deuszu_imdugud
66.body: They do run on jet fuel as well as other fuels. The reporter wasn't wrong just not terribly informed. And yes even those who knew this in the US military still used the jet fuel excuse.

67.author: veritasanmortem
67.body:
I guess that’s a good point. There is no point in that kind of thing from someone that thinks:

1. A CMOS chip isn’t a chip (what exactly is processing the output from the APS and how exactly does the thermal data get processed and presented into a human readable form…never mind the chips in the fire control and combat information systems?) 
2. Doesn’t remember how everything was stripped from nearly every physical plant and piece of military hardware over the 1990s leaving a nation that even today is unable to satisfy its own supply chains and has thousands of pieces of military hardware that is effectively unusable, except by Russians since they don’t really care if they send their pilots into the air with cheap Chinese handheld GPSs and their soldiers into tanks with the electronic systems torn out and scraped long ago for the copper and other metals so some senior lieutenant could buy some vodka or some major general could build a house. 
3. Doesn’t know the Russian culture of vranyo and how as a result, doesn’t know that repeating Russian sources without actually personally witnessing the item in question is a recipe for misunderstanding the real situation. (Just ask anyone that wrote stories about the Russian military and military power before 24 February 2022 and how they look like fools today)
4. Has never worked with a Russian company or had to get something approved by a Russian ministry and therefore has no idea of what Russian blat is and how convoluted, inefficient, and often criminal process are required to make anything happen. (Only to get shoddy work back, often far outside of spec with the cheapest Western and Chinese shit inside)
5. Doesn’t understand that a wealthy Russian wouldn’t invest capital into a physical plant in Russia (especially a factory requiring expensive high tech hardware) because it would eventually be taken from him, especially when they can just buy crap from China or even high quality inputs from the west and charge the MoD multiples of the COGS for just assembling the end product. Even under sanctions, it is much easier to either bust the sanctions or outright steal your inputs. 

You would take anything I would bring up and just double down and triple down on the bs told before. (Which is undoubtedly what you are about to do again as I’m sure you will respond to this with more of the same.)

67.author: Orcasubmarine
67.body:
Im well aware of those things.   
The problem is that none of those things are related to the discussion at hand.   
You think that because they lie about some things, they automatically lie about everything.   
**Causation does not imply correlation.**

67.author: veritasanmortem
67.body:
They lie about everything. Absolutely everything. They lie to cover up their other lies. There are different terms in Russian to describe the layers of lies. Russia is a criminal syndicate masquerading as a country. I personally knew a Russian businessman that was arrested and later killed in a fraudulent tax criminal complaint. His assets were seized and “sold” to a group run by the very MVD officer who filed the criminal complaint for less than a kopek on the ruble. That officer was building a business empire of his own.  This is how business was done in Russia in the 2000s and nothing has changed today.  

Here is the key for me: don’t listen to what they say, look at how they actually do. The technologically advanced Russian armed forces was operating 50 year old tanks (not designs, actual T-72As and T-62s), trucks and BTRs with dry rotted tires, electronic warfare systems that were so bad that they were forced to turn them off, no basic logistical support to get fuel, food, and ammo to their soldiers, an Air Force unable to fly over the battlefield, cheap Iranian drones that they are forced to paid for with Su-35s (Assuming they don’t end up screwing the Iranians), tanks without electronics, aircraft without integrated avionics, entire formations with only half their men, and a hundred other examples of military vranyo. It was so bad that they were forced to spread the lie that they were holding back the “real” varsity troops and equipment…and just wait for those forces to really kick the Ukrainians ass. (Remember that lie, to cover up the lie that the RF armed forces were the “second army”)

But if it is easier to imagine that what Russia says is the truth so you can just read about a topic on the internet and get your nerd on, then you do you.

67.author: Orcasubmarine
67.body:
Not everything, but close.   
And the story you've told is just the classic example of the widespread corruption, that permeates everything in the Russian society.  
   
But in order to keep the corruption going, they will still need to deliver SOME products, just not all of them.   
So previously mentioned sights and tanks, they are infact real enough.   
But because of the corruption, they will most likely never be adopted in massive scale. 

Leaving them to rely on old T-72A and BTR-80's, instead of T-14 and VPK-7829 Bumerangs. 

The Pantsir tire thing, was debunked by the way.   
They used michelin tires. (Though eventually, they will be forced to go with Chinese, when their supply runs out):

67.author: veritasanmortem
67.body:
Debunked by Russian sources or just those sources that got their information from the Russians?  Seriously, nothing in Russia is as it seems.  Nothing. 

Corruption doesn’t need products. Here is an example: A PMC wants a tank, they buy the tank from existing stocks of MoD tanks, everyone in the deal chain gets a cut, then the PMC contracts with the MoD (or RF in general) for a given service, the MoD pays several times the going rate for the contract, the PMC kicks back to everyone in the deal chain. The PMC eventually loses the tank and charges the MoD for equipment expenses at several times the cost of the tank, pockets the proceeds while kicking back money to everyone in the deal chain.  Note, nothing was created. The MoD got money for the tank, which they ultimately had to buy back at a premium, the PMC paid for an old tank, but ended up with more money than when they started, and the blat system ensured that the old boys network of deal makers and syndicates all got a cut. The only one that loses in this deal is the Russian people (and the three pieces of fodder in the tank). This is a simple scheme, the real deal is multilayered and might produce 5 times the value of the tank for nothing more than a broken down stripped out tank which was built by the Soviet Union 40 years ago. Building a couple tanks a month isn’t going to cut it (and doesn’t need more than a couple of fixers to source the components to finalize the sale…even if they are shit Chinese parts and don’t really do what they should).

Because there's more oversight and the people care.   
Where's in Russia there's this social contract "We don't care about politics, as long as you don't mobilize us to fight and let us have our comforts".   
Which is also a part of the reason, why it's called a special military operation and the mobilization is only "partial".   
if he had declared war, and mobilized like WWII, the Russian people would have rebelled. 

Also Wagner is mostly a PMC in name only, in reality they are just a another part of the Russian MOD.

68.author: bigorangemachine
68.body:
[Grabbed this clip](https://youtu.be/LYeeMeKg-NM?t=199) from the speak the truth podcast/youtube channel. I have five-less-than-five-minute-clips I'm working on uploading of this really interesting interview.  Speak the Truth interviews a Ukrainian  speaking ~~ex-US-army-soldier~~ (I might be misremembering this) member of the foreign legion (but not attached to the foreign legion) providing first hand accounts.  In a later clip he retells an account of his brother who is in the Armoured Forces of the UAF.  In a prior interview he mentions how ~~he ended up in the US army and his brother didn't but IIRC~~ (I might be misremembering this) they are both Ukrainian born.  Also from a prior interview he mentions how he helped train members of the UAF to use NLAW with no prior training just translating manuals and 'hacking' the Javelins to work with car batteries for training.

Below is the editted (for corrections & clarity but not editorialized) youtube transcript for anyone with shoddy internet.

This is a continuation of [the story/clip I posted here](https://www.reddit.com/r/UkraineWarVideoReport/comments/10k5o94/uaf_sf_whatever_you_need_they_have_it_language/).

>So we're in the middle of this groove it's kind of Chasm I guess.  
>  
>It's real deep like twenty at least 20 feet 25 feet maybe and it's only four feet wide and it goes snakes like this \[motions "S" Snake-like motion with single-hand\] and it gets to the top. We're at the bottom of this thing it's perfect place where artillery can't get you. There's there's not an angle that \[artillery\] can just fly into it and get you and we're at the very bottom of the chasm. We cut the shelves on both sides we're sleeping in the shelves that's this tall \[motions about 3 feet or about 1 meter\] so really... It's a hard clay too so all the walls are very stable. You know it just you can't dig a better really better position. It was awesome!  
>  
>So we dug that in that's where we're hunkered for the night in the morning. We woke up went down to the vehicles. The vehicles are in the bushes right by the water. All this this position has been abandoned since we pushed the enemies like 60 kilometers past that area.  
>  
>\[Just\] So you know things I talk about is no secret by any means anymore.  
>  
>We parked the vehicles in in a thick brush cover them up and in the morning we're out there we had a little stove we're four kilometers from the enemy. We're in the bushes we're doing okay. We had a stove we're just cooking some food just having a good time. Him & I just chatting getting to know each other waiting for orders \[and waiting\] for the rest there's more guys are supposed to come that day; but again because we got engaged during the day they had to wait till night to infill \[infiltrate\].  
>  
>So sitting there talking next thing you know there's an artillery incoming right above the positions where we're taking shelter for the night. Just explosion "bam" and it rains the shrapnel on top of us so we kind of look at that thinking hmm... well that was strange and then "boom" another one and then look at him and say I wonder if they spotted the vehicles maybe from a drone like a windshield  \[Host: "some shine"\] reflection or something.  
>  
>I thought "I wonder if they're after Vehicles"... they're just trying to zero in he goes "yeah that may be he's like we got to take cover" because where we are is concealment there is no cover in the bushes. So we wait usually takes the tank around I don't know 20 seconds to reach there. So we wait as soon as the explosion happens we just rush to get to this one \[foxhole\]; get to our shelves you know take cover and they shot at us 22 times! They shot the whole carousel at us. We figured out by the explosion but the sound that there was a tank working on us; I thought "hmm I don't think we made that many mistakes".  How could they... how could they have found us. So we sit in there contemplating...  
>  
>I mean we're safe I mean I have a photo where I'm holding pieces of shrapnel that they \[was firing\] was raining on top of us and... Yeah maybe you can insert that photo.. I don't know it's it's a cool photo okay I'm proud of it.  
>  
>Umm... so we're sitting there talking and then I said "well you know it's been quiet for an hour I'm gonna go down to the vehicle and grab some food"... and the guy's like "no you're not going anywhere until it's dark".  
>  
>This is the difference between normal soldier and a SF \[special forces\]. Like he was soooo... It was...  We \[were\] sitting there all day we had some water we had no food. Because all the food was down there where we were cooking it & that was the difference between him and everybody else... Somebody more casual would be like oh yeah sure you know crawl or whatever be quiet; but he's like no we got spotted so we're gonna hunker down. So after this-this shots were going on for a while...  
>  
>He counted \[he was counting the shots\]. That's another thing he-he counted the shots because he wanted to know... what it you know... just wanted to know. So it was 22 times and then at the end of it he went to investigate um what's going on. He went around to this uh crack \[in the earth probably means ditch\] went up there and he came back.  
>  
>He's like hey I heard voices on top somebody was "yelling heavy 300"; that somebody was also yelling he's like "what do we do?! what do we do?!" \[soldier from the other unit was panicking\]. So what we come to learn that day & also that night: there was a group... \[aside\] We traveled... "One" we traveled at night "Two" when we moved during the day we moved along the Black Sea along the bushes. So we're in complete cover somebody from people "we don't know" the unit on top was walking on the plains on the higher plains they're the ones that got spotted. They happened to be above us. We had a position you couldn't possibly see us so they were walking on top of us when they got spotted and got engaged by the tank. One of them ended up being a heavy 300 \[aside\] (300 means uh injured); so one of them ended up being heavily wounded and he didn't make it.  
>  
>There was no there's no x-fill \[exfiltrate/exfiltration for casualties\] we got engaged 14 kilometers away... spotted. We were four kilometers now there isn't a vehicle that was going to drive out there and get him.

84.author: pw1978-2
84.body:
The good news is the Russians have been idiots so far. They may continue to be idiots, but I wouldn’t bet the national survival on it. Russia has been very successful at hybrid war for decades. In a way, this phase of the Ukrainian war is abnormal. The Russians clearly thought that Germany was on their side and that Germany would not support Ukraine given how important Russia trade was to Germany. 

Unfortunately, the war is still young and we all fear that Russia might still be right about Germany not supporting Ukraine as Russia slowly eliminates the Ukrainian nation and people. If Russia succeeds, they have made it absolutely clear that the Baltic states are next.  It might be years from now, but eventually Germany will be forced to fight for its survival, but against a much stronger and more populous Russia.

84.author: SterlingArchers
84.body: The thing is: i can't wrap my head around the concept of Germany siding with Russia. This simply isn't the case and can't ever be. Russia turns into a western democracy first before Germany turns into a Russian ally

84.author: pw1978-2
84.body:
Maybe “side with” is too strong a phrase. Germany and Russia have developed a strong trade and geopolitical relationship for many years (decades actually). I think there are three things going on here. The SPD has maintained very strong ties to the Russians (both with Russian businesses specifically and the country in general) and many have retired to Russian sinecures and maintain personal relations across the border.  The Germans have become reliant on very cheap energy. The Germans believed the liberalization of Russia (and hence improved European security) would be a natural outcome of a strong German-Russian relationship. 

Unfortunately, Russia is a criminal organization that masquerades as a nation. Every new trade deal or negotiated international agreement with Russia was like making a deal with the Mafia, Yakuza, or Bratva.
